results.headline: Love Triangle Sideshow, a Circus’s Main Attraction
results.summary_short: Francis Lawrence directs Reese Witherspoon and Robert Pattinson in “Water for Elephants,” a film adaptation of Sara Gruen’s novel about a Depression-era traveling circus.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Water for Elephants

results.headline: A Tale of the Jazz Age, One With Flying Kicks
results.summary_short: “Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen” mines again that kung fu mother lode “Fist of Fury,” this time for an adventure set in Shanghai after World War I.
results.display_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen

results.headline: Siblings on the Road
results.summary_short: “Exodus Fall” is Ankush Kohli and Chad Waterhouses’s road movie, set in 1974.

results.headline: ‘Dumbstruck’ Shows Ventriloquists’ World
results.summary_short: “Dumbstruck” documents the world of ventriloquists.

results.headline: ‘African Cats,’ Is Disneynature’s Look at Lions
results.summary_short: “African Cats” tells the story of lions and cheetahs and the power of mother love.

results.headline: A Difficult Family Relationship
results.summary_short: Janet Grillo’s “Fly Away” is an unsentimental look at the complex codependency between a harried single mother and her severely autistic daughter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fly Away

results.headline: Family Portrait
results.summary_short: The Italian director Paolo Virzì paints a rich portrait of a family, told in a mother’s deathbed flashbacks, in “The First Beautiful Thing.”

results.headline: Romance or Film Noir? Both, and a Thriller
results.summary_short: The plot of “The Double Hour” is so complex that only a vigilant detective could piece it together.

results.headline: Macaw Finds His Wings, and Much More, in Brazil
results.summary_short: An animated comedy about a blue macaw’s adventures in Rio, with the voice of Jesse Eisenberg as Blu, the macaw.

results.headline: Pawn, Prize and Beauty, So Submit She Must
results.summary_short: “The Princess of Montpensier,” Bertrand Tavernier’s period tale about wars on the battlefield and those closer to home, is a rousing amalgam of ambition, moods and genre conceits.

results.headline: Émigrés in New York Who Aren’t Outsiders
results.summary_short: “The Imperialists Are Still Alive!,” written and directed by Zeina Durra, follows Middle Eastern immigrants whose lives revolve around art galleries and parties.

results.headline: History’s Loose Ends, and a Tightening Noose
results.summary_short: “The Conspirator,” Robert Redford’s latest turn as director, imagines the path of justice in the aftermath of Lincoln’s assassination.

results.headline: Adventures in the Drug Trades
results.summary_short: “Square Grouper” is a documentary about pot smuggling in South Florida in the 1970s and ’80s.

results.headline: The Shrieks Continue
results.summary_short: The director Wes Craven’s core team has reassembled for “Scream 4,” and the action has returned to Woodsboro, scene of the original 1996 film.

results.headline: Arrested Development and Second Chances
results.summary_short: In “Phillip the Fossil,” a high school star gone to seed in a small New England town tries to turn his life around.

results.headline: Colorful Lives and Tragic Deaths
results.summary_short: “Footprints,” is a love letter to a Hollywood long gone.

results.headline: Fortunes and Misfortunes of War, From a Danish Perspective
results.summary_short: This documentary follows troops in Helmand Province in Afghanistan into a firefight and its aftermath.

results.headline: A Pool Man in Chad, at the Intersection of the Personal and the Political
results.summary_short: “A Screaming Man,” by the Chadian-born filmmaker Mahamat-Saleh Haroun, is a tender story about an individual at the intersection of the personal and the political.

results.headline: The Bollywood Treatment, for Husbands
results.summary_short: “Thank You,” Anees Bazmee’s Bollywood production set in Vancouver, has two-timing husbands running for cover.

results.headline: A ‘Freak Folk’ Music Moment
